Short answer: don’t give leftover antibiotics. They won’t “knock out” a cold (which is almost always viral) and can cause real harm.

Why not give them
- Antibiotics treat bacteria, not viruses. Most colds, bronchiolitis, and flu are viral and won’t get better faster with antibiotics.
- Risks of giving leftover antibiotics: allergic reaction (which can be severe), side effects like vomiting or diarrhea, incorrect drug or dose for your child’s age/weight, and promoting antibiotic resistance.
- Leftovers may be expired or the wrong antibiotic for whatever infection might actually be present.

When antibiotics are appropriate
Antibiotics should only be used when a clinician has diagnosed a bacterial infection (examples: confirmed strep throat, a diagnosed urinary tract infection, some cases of bacterial pneumonia or certain ear/sinus infections that meet clinical criteria). A provider should prescribe the right drug and dose for your child.

What to do now
- Don’t give the antibiotics. Contact your pediatrician’s on-call line or nurse triage — most offices have an after-hours number.
- If you can’t reach them and you’re worried, go to urgent care or the emergency department.

Red flags that need immediate evaluation
Get immediate medical care (call 911 or go to the ED) if your child has:
- Trouble breathing, very fast breathing, wheezing, or lips/face turning blue
- Severe lethargy/unresponsiveness or hard to wake
- Signs of severe dehydration (very few/no wet diapers, dry mouth, no tears, sunken fontanelle in an infant)
- High fever in a baby under 3 months (rectal temp ≥100.4°F / 38°C)
- High fever that’s very persistent or >104°F (40°C), or fever with a rash (especially petechial/purple spots), neck stiffness, or severe pain
- A severe allergic reaction (hives, swelling of face/lips/tongue, trouble breathing)

Supportive care you can use for a typical cold
- Keep them hydrated and rested
- Saline nose drops and suction for infants
- Fever/pain control: acetaminophen or ibuprofen (ibuprofen only if child is ≥6 months). If you want exact dosing, tell me your child’s age and weight and I can calculate it, or check the dosing instructions on the medication and confirm with the pediatrician.
- Humidified air or a steamy bathroom can help nasal congestion

How to talk to your mother-in-law
You can be firm but polite: “I appreciate that you want to help, but antibiotics can be dangerous if given when they’re not needed. Our pediatrician wants us to call first so they can decide the right treatment.” If she keeps insisting, say you’ll ask the doctor.

If you want, tell me your child’s age and weight and I can:
- Help with safe dosing for acetaminophen/ibuprofen, or
- Suggest wording for the on-call nurse, or
- Help decide whether your child needs urgent care now.

If you’re truly worried right now or notice any red-flag symptoms above, seek emergency care.

- Confirmed bacterial infections:
  - Streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat): treat if a rapid strep or throat culture is positive.
  - Bacterial pneumonia: suspected with high fever, shortness of breath, focal chest findings, low oxygen, or an abnormal chest x‑ray—requires antibiotics.
  - Bacterial skin, urinary tract or other clear bacterial infections—treat per diagnosis.
- Likely bacterial sinusitis: consider antibiotics only when symptoms are severe (high fever and purulent nasal discharge or facial pain) at onset, symptoms persist >10 days without improvement, or there is “double worsening” (initial improvement then relapse/worsening).
- Acute otitis media in children: antibiotic treatment is indicated in many cases based on age, severity, and examination findings (follow pediatric guidelines).

- “Watchful waiting” or a delayed prescription is often safe for borderline cases—give symptomatic care now and start antibiotics only if symptoms meet the criteria above or worsen.
- If someone is high risk (immunosuppressed, very young, very old, pregnant with severe symptoms, or has significant lung disease), evaluate more aggressively and consider antibiotics sooner.

- Symptomatic measures: fluids, rest, acetaminophen/ibuprofen for fever/pain, saline nasal rinses, throat lozenges, humidifiers, cough remedies appropriate for age.
- Antivirals when indicated (flu/COVID) if within appropriate window and patient meets criteria.

Guidelines by audience and goals
- Elementary (ages 6–11): Minimal (3–5% of lesson time). Teach the simple rule: “Antibiotics fight bacteria, not viruses.” Use clear examples (strep throat vs. colds/flu) and a short activity. Don’t dive into molecular mechanisms.

- High school (ages 15–18): Moderate (20–30%). Give a more developed explanation of antibiotic targets (cell wall, ribosomes, metabolic enzymes) vs. viral reliance on host machinery. - Intro college / pre-health: Substantial (30–40%). Go deeper into mechanisms of action and antiviral strategies, discuss resistance mechanisms, diagnostic implications, and stewardship principles. Include primary-source reading or problem-based learning.

- Analogy: bacteria = independent factories (antibiotics break specific machines); viruses = intruders using your factory’s machines (you can’t break your own machines without harm).
- Visuals: side-by-side diagrams of bacterial cell vs. virus and a flowchart showing drug targets.
- Case studies: “patient with sore throat” scenarios where students decide if antibiotics are appropriate.

Why firm restrictions are needed

1. Default: “No antibiotics for presumed viral respiratory infections.” That includes uncomplicated acute bronchitis, viral upper respiratory infection/common cold, most pharyngitis without positive strep test, and most non‑purulent conjunctivitis.

- Prohibit antibiotics for acute bronchitis and uncomplicated URI by default.

Practical probability thresholds (reasonable working rules)
- <10–20% probability of bacterial infection: do not prescribe antibiotics. Use symptomatic care and safety‑netting.
- 20–50% (intermediate): consider observation/“watchful waiting”, use point‑of‑care tests (rapid strep, flu test, CRP/procalcitonin), or give a delayed prescription.

- >80% (high probability/severe disease): treat promptly.

How to estimate probability — clinical clues that increase likelihood of bacterial infection
- Focal signs on exam (lobar crackles, consolidation, otoscopic signs of acute otitis media).

- Purulent sputum alone is a poor discriminator (common in viral and chronic airways disease).
- Marked leukocytosis with left shift supports bacterial infection.
- Risk factors: very young or old age, immunosuppression, significant cardiopulmonary disease, recent antibiotic use.

Condition‑specific guidance (common respiratory diagnoses)
- Common cold / acute URTI: almost always viral. No antibiotics.

- Pharyngitis: use Centor/McIsaac scoring and/or rapid antigen detection test (RADT). Adults with low score (0–1) do not need testing or antibiotics. RADT positive → treat; RADT negative → usually no antibiotics.
- Acute rhinosinusitis: antibiotics only for severe symptoms (high fever, purulent nasal discharge, facial pain) or symptoms >10 days without improvement, or worsening after initial improvement. Otherwise supportive care or delayed prescription.
- Acute otitis media (children): consider age, bilaterality, and severity. Many cases can be observed for 48–72 hours with analgesia; treat earlier for severe illness, <2 years with bilateral disease, or systemic toxicity.
- Community‑acquired pneumonia: antibiotics indicated when clinical and/or radiographic evidence of pneumonia exists. Use severity scores (CURB‑65) to guide site of care and urgency. Consider procalcitonin to help decide antibiotic need in ambiguous cases.
- Suspected pertussis: macrolide recommended to limit transmission.

- Rapid antigen test for Group A Strep: high specificity — positive = treat. Negative in suspicious cases might need confirmatory testing in children.
- Influenza rapid PCR/antigen: positive supports viral diagnosis and can reduce unnecessary antibiotics; offers antivirals if within window.
- C‑reactive protein (CRP): helpful at point of care. CRP <20 mg/L suggests viral/no antibiotics; 20–100 mg/L is indeterminate; >100 mg/L favors bacterial infection.
- Procalcitonin: low values (<0.25 µg/L) strongly argue against bacterial lower respiratory tract infection; higher values support antibiotics.
- Chest X‑ray: useful when pneumonia suspected or diagnosis uncertain.

- Explain rationale to patients: expected course, harms of antibiotics (side effects, resistance), and red flags that require reassessment.
- Offer symptomatic measures and a specific plan: when to return, when to start delayed prescription (e.g., if worse after 48–72 h), or to start immediately.
- Use shortest effective antibiotic course when treating.

Bottom line
You don’t need absolute certainty. Aim to be confident enough that the probability of bacterial disease is low before withholding antibiotics (typically <10–20%).
